dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you doing today? Feel free to share whatever's on your mind. I'm here to listen.
Hey, thanks for asking. I've been feeling really overwhelmed with school lately, like everything's just too much. I've been thinking a lot about taking a break to focus on myself.

It sounds like the demands of school are really weighing on you, leading you to consider taking a break to take care of your well-being. What aspects of school are making you feel most overwhelmed right now?

client(exploring): It's mostly the people, to be honest. I feel like I don't fit in with my classmates and my professors just add to the stress. Plus, the workload is never-ending, and I just feel burnt out.

It can be really tough when you feel disconnected from your peers and overwhelmed by the expectations of professors. You're feeling burnt out because of the constant workload and social pressures. Could you share more about your experiences with your classmates and professors?

client(exploring): Yeah, for sure. I just feel like I have nothing in common with my classmates, and everything feels so competitive. As for the professors, it seems like they don't really care about what we're going through, you know? It's like they're just piling on the work without considering how it affects us.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their thoughts and feelings about feeling overwhelmed by school pressures and social disconnection. The therapist has successfully elicited the essence of the client's situation, creating an empathetic and supportive environment. Mutually agreed goals, such as considering a break for personal growth and mental health, have started to emerge. Moving to the Guiding phase would be appropriate to strengthen motivation and explore options.

dialogue.statement: It must be challenging to feel like you're in a competitive environment where you don't fully connect with others, and that your struggles aren't being acknowledged by professors. Thinking about all of this, what might your life be like if you took that break you're considering?

client(guiding): Honestly, I think it would be like a reset button for me. I'd have the chance to explore new places, learn things at my own pace, and just breathe without all this pressure. It feels like a year off could really help me find some clarity and figure out what I truly want.
Taking a break sounds like it could offer you a chance to reset and rediscover what truly matters to you. What aspects of exploring new places and learning at your own pace excite you the most?

I think it's the freedom and adventure that really excites me, like being able to immerse myself in new cultures and just absorb everything around me without any deadlines. Plus, the chance to learn new languages sounds amazing because it's something I've always wanted to do, but never had the time for.

The thought of freedom and adventure is really energizing for you, and the idea of immersing yourself in new cultures and learning languages is something you truly value. On a scale of 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about taking this break and pursuing these experiences?

client(guiding): I'd say I'm around a 7 or 8 right now. I feel pretty confident that it could really help me, but there's still a part of me that's worried about what taking a year off might mean for my future.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a desire to take a year off, showing Change Talk and enthusiasm for the break. They've identified specific goals, like traveling and learning languages, and rated their confidence at 7-8. Thereâ€™s a clear discrepancy between their current situation and their values. Despite a bit of ambivalence, the guiding phase goals are met, indicating readiness to move forward.

dialogue.statement: Taking a year off feels exciting and beneficial, yet it's natural to have concerns about its implications for your future. To navigate this, let's explore what steps you might take to prepare for this break while considering those future concerns. Some options could be reaching out to advisors about your academic plans or researching programs that align with your interests. What do you think might be a helpful first step for you?

client(choosing): I think talking to an academic advisor could be a good start. They might be able to help me figure out how to pause my studies without it being a huge issue later on. Plus, looking into some travel programs or volunteer opportunities might give me a better idea of what's out there and help me plan something meaningful.

Connecting with an academic advisor seems like a practical first step to address your concerns and gain clarity on pausing your studies. Exploring travel programs or volunteer opportunities could further solidify your plans and help you envision a meaningful break. What do you think about setting a goal to schedule a meeting with an advisor this week and researching at least two travel or volunteer programs by next week? How can you prepare for any challenges that might arise as you take these steps?

client(choosing): That sounds like a solid plan. I'll aim to set up a meeting with the advisor this week and start checking out some travel programs. I guess I could write down any questions or concerns I have before meeting with the advisor, so I don't miss anything important. As for researching programs, I might make a list of what I want to gain from the experience to help me focus.

Preparing questions for your advisor and listing what you want from travel programs are great strategies to stay focused and informed. This approach helps you address any concerns and find programs that truly resonate with your goals. How do you feel about checking in next week to review your progress and discuss any new insights or challenges you've encountered along the way?

client(choosing): Yeah, that sounds like a good idea. I think having a check-in will keep me accountable and help me process everything that's happening. Plus, it might be nice to talk through any hurdles I hit while I'm figuring things out.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified a clear goal of taking a year off and has developed a concrete action plan involving meeting with an academic advisor and researching travel programs. They have also prepared strategies for potential barriers, such as preparing questions for the advisor. The client shows commitment and confidence, accepting the action plan and agreeing to self-monitoring through a check-in.

dialogue.statement: Staying accountable and processing your journey is indeed beneficial. Setting up a check-in next week will give you the space to reflect on your progress and any challenges you face. You've set a strong foundation by planning to meet with your advisor and researching programs. Remember, each step you take is a move towards clarity and fulfillment. I'm here to support you through this exciting path. Keep embracing the adventure, and we'll touch base soon to continue navigating this together.
That sounds good. I'll get started on these things and keep moving forward. Thanks for your support; looking forward to our next chat!

statement.reasoning: The client has developed a clear action plan with defined steps for moving forward, including meeting with an advisor and researching travel programs, meeting termination goals.

concern:
title: i want to take a year off of my second year in college
I really regret not taking this year off but I'm passing it because I have a good grades, but i really want to take the next year off i want to travel around the world and work on myself, learn another languages , and most importantly work on my mental health, i also can't stand my classmates and my professors i hate every minute I'm spending it with those fu*kers, i just want to take a full year off, is that bad am i ruining my future
